These two sentences:  

> I'm experianced with computers

> I'm using the option bootsect.bin bootsector and not grub4dos
cannot logically exist in the same post as they are mutually exclusive. :tongue:  

Up to you to choose which one to remove in order to be able to make steps in the right direction.  

Then, take your time on the Rules page, and have a look at the "common sense advice", it is not of course mandatory, but usually it helps, right now we are in the "I'm ill Doctor, help!" phase:  
[http://homepages.tes...ard-litany.html](http://homepages.tesco.net/J.deBoynePollard/FGA/problem-report-standard-litany.html "External link")  

What you reported WITHOUT any meaningful detail is that you tried two or three different methods and got two or three unspecified errors.  

> so I figure that bootsect.bin bootsector isn't a standard xp boot.
bootsect.bin is a name of a file: it's contents could be ANYTHING.  
Normally that name is used for a 2,048 bytes in size bootsector used on CD's and DVD's which has NOTHING to do with "XP", but that is used to load Windows NT family SETUP CD's or Windows PE's (LiveXP is a PE 1.x, based on XP/Server 2003 sources) CD's, used as no-emulation bootsector.  

A USB stick is a device that is similar to a hard disk, it normally uses sectors (and a bootsector) sized 512 bytes, besides in most cases the device needs to be partitioned and have a MBR too, OBVIOUSLY a 2048 bytes bootsector designed to work on CD's won't work aon a HD-like device.  

The answer to the original question is:  
> how to kiss a bootable usb drive?
Unless you have a Water Resistant USB stick, like one of this:  
[http://www.supertale...l.php?type=Pico](http://www.supertalent.com/products/stt_usb_detail.php?type=Pico "External link")  

DO NOT, and when I say DO NOT I mean DO NOT french-kiss it. ![:mellow:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/mellow.png)

**Creating a bootable USB device the EASY way** ok since no one's willing to take the glove I will. The following procedure isn't fully compatible with all of the recent computers but it's a start. farther testing \& tweaking is needed. Also your USB device gets formatted twice so move your files elsewhere edit: the procedure's meant for the XP project. The Vista/Win7 Projects weren't that user friendly to say the least... This involve two steps: 1. to get the boot files you can also use only step 1. to create the boot but the tool in step 2. has more options and may be needed for large usb thumbdrives (and for compatibility)


Step 1. if you already have the boot files skip to step 2. a. download and use PeToUSB (google it) b. format the usb device with the 'enable LBA (fat 16x)' option source path is WinBuilder\\Target\\project name c. save the following boot files from the USB device: 'ntldr', 'ntdetect', 'winbom.ini' the file/s have pointers to specific directories/files in them so copying them from your installed windows won't work.


Step 2. a. download and usb RMPrepUSB from [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=7739](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7739 "External link") b. Use the option XP/Winpe v1/BartPE bootable (ntldr) Make sure that: boot as HDD is marked 'force use of LBA calls' is checked for small drives 'use 64d/32sec if possible' for large drive (bigger then 8GB?) Or simply try the last option and see if it works c. copy the boot files (from step 1 or ones that you got before hand) d. copy the project to your usb device from Winbuilder\\target\\project name rename the folder I386 to minint
As I said before the above boot options worked on new dell laptops but didn't work on a sami old sami new Intel Motherboard Desktop so farther testing \& tweaking's needed When I'll have the time...

Try the above but without the HDD tick box (i.e. FDD, ZIP and HDD all unticked). Some BIOSes do not like 2 partitions. Also some Intel BIOSes have a Boot as Removable or Fixed option - it needs to be set to Fixed.

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
> Try the above but without the HDD tick box (i.e. FDD, ZIP and HDD all unticked). Some BIOSes do not like 2 partitions.

Also, you don't need to do any copying, etc. The BartPe checkbox in RMPrepUSb runs what petousb does.  

so just prepare a bootable i386 folder using PEuilder or WinBuilder, then point RMPrepUSB at the folder which contains the i386 folder you have just made, tick the COPY and BartPE tickboxes and it will do it all for you in one step.  

Download v2.0.801 which has some more info on what the BartPE checkbox does. v801 is near the last post in RMPrepUSB topic.
